Katanagatari is yet another -gatari "story" (forgive my pun), written by none other then the Monogatari legend him self Nisio Isin or NisioisiN.  As his cleaver pen name implies this guy really loves his word play.  This is something very common to all of his works and Katanagatari is definitely no slouch in that department.   In my opinion katanagatari is one of the most unique/interesting anime to come along in the last generation in so far as plot, character and dialogue driven anime goes.  Before I go into to detail as to why I hold this anime in high praise,I will say quite bluntly that if you have not watched Katanagatari then you should, However, by that point you'll have been torn to pieces.  


As far as the story is concerned, a 10 is almost too understating.  This is not to say that the story of Katanagatari is absolutely flawless or that there is no other anime that lives up to this story, there certainly are other anime that are just as good if not better in different respects (story-wise).  Katanagatari runs the full gamete in terms of what it actually does.  Not only is the writing top notch but the structure, themes and metaphors behind the story are very well crafted.  This makes for a very unconventional anime that masks its self as a very conventional journey anime et la samurai champloo.  Its almost as though Katanagatari is a deconstruction of this style of anime in the same way that puella magi madoka magica was a deconstruction of the magical girl anime or in the same way evangelion was for mecha.  Of course though, this genera of anime isn't as well founded as magical girls or mecha anime but its still a similar style in the sense that it is a "realistic" interpretation at least as far as the plot and characters are conserned.   Never did was I able to guess where the anime would go next when it threw a curve ball nor did I imagine that it would turn out so complex at the end, however, it is able to do this so very well all while balancing emotion/action and comedy.  


The art direction is very akin to the afore mentioned Samurai Champloo with mixes of Monogatari as well as some of its own unique takes.  Some portions look like they were taken from Visual novels while others look absolutely gorgeous.  There is a very minimalist approach here that works to complement the more complex writing character art.  The character art and animations are very fluid and well done as well as deceptive and serve to help each of the characters flesh out into their own unique personas.  Overall the art is up there with other top notch shows produced by studio giants of the like of Kyoto Animation or Shaft while not being too avant garde to take away from its audience. 


The sound track and sound samples are all amazing.  They create great atmosphere and help complement the complex emotions that fit in the very long signature dialogue scenes and the very fast paced action sequences.  The voice acting is extremely well done as well, with each character truly being fleshed out by all involved.  Even the small side characters are very well received and can stand on their own with such great voice acting.  Each voice actor delivers their lines with such gusto and such bravado as well as great timing.  Again, though the real stand out here is the musical score, I really cant say that enough.


Each of the many characters are very fleshed out with complex yet some times simplistic motives.  In particular, the two lead characters pull you in.  They make you love and sometimes hate them.  The character development is what makes all of this work so well.  From the first episode to the last, each of the characters change in ways that are very realistic yet surprising at the same time.  Everyone from the narrator who states the obvious to the side characters play their roles perfectly creating a very believable world even with all these "supernatural-type" powers.  Each one has his or her own identity as well as own motive in the plot and each one is neither good nor bad when you really break things down.  


One thing i would be remiss to not talk about is the dialogue and the overall writing.  Japanese word play is different then English because of Kanji, with each character meaning more then one thing in most cases, we have times when the writing uses these multiple meanings to its advantage.  And of course since this is a NisioisiN work, the dialogue is very very long winded but with good reason.  His style of telling most of the story through a series of conversations works very well here as it serves to allow the audience to fully grasp the emotions of each of the characters as well as their motivations.  Metaphor is scattered everywhere with tons and tons of very complex ideas that may not be very apparent from the get go view.  After viewing this show a few times, i still find things that I missed out on, in previous occasions.  


In the end, Katanagatari is a great anime for anyone who likes anime in general but also in specific for people who enjoy good writing, good action and stories that may or may not have a happy ending, aka realist stories.  In my opinion it is an achievement in anime that reminds me that anime is also an art form that can be as serious as the most beautiful painting or piece of literature.   I know i gave this entire thing a 10 out of 10 for everything, but honestly, it really resonated with me that much.  You may not see it as a shining beacon of awesome like I do, but I guarantee you will enjoy your self even if you dont, However, by that point you'll have been torn to pieces.

Watching a beautiful story unfold before your very eyes is insanely rare yet on occasions you find one series that manages to tell an epic story that leaves you with a void inside knowing that you’ll never experience anything like that ever again.  Well, I’m about to talk about a series where many feel this exact same way I do, Katanagatgari!
Katanagatari was an anime released in 2010 created by White Fox containing 12 episodes, 50 minutes in length.  Its genres include Action, Adventure and Martial Arts! 
The Story
Synopsis
Katanagatari’s story initiates when Togame, a strategist, searches for Shichika, a person who studies Kyoutoryuu.Kyuoutoryuu is essentially a fighting style that resembles sword wielding without actually holding a sword.  After finding him on an island and having troubles with an enemy they both embark on a journey searching for 12 Legendary Deviant Blades located across Edo Era Japan.  Togame is the strategist, and Shichika is her sword, together their story unfolds as we observe their interactions with each other, the abnormal people they encounter and learn the true meaning of what it means to be human.


You see, Katanagatari isn’t necessarily about the sword collecting but moreso about shaping Shichika’s character into becoming more human from his initial amoral emotionless self.  Even though he’s under the contracted ownership of Togame as her sword, Shichika after leaving his home island learns each episode about a new element of what makes someone a human which ties into multiple more themes that are fleshed out, some relating to my favorite philosophy ever! Existentialism!  Shichika constantly gains the ability of free will while struggling to find a purpose in life which is rewarding to watch.  However, even though it’s existential, the story of Katanagatari is in the grand scheme of things, pointless.  But the reason for the story’s existence is because it’s a story worth being told, the adventures are truly spectacular and unique in their own way which holds a ton of valuable storytelling.  


What would this show be without its dialogue?  Eh, probably trash.  It is also a show dedicated to presenting some of the most genius and engaging dialogue I’ve ever seen.  The conversations usually accumulate up to 95% of the episode.  Even though the dialogue is hefty with some of the diction being anomalous, it never invoked any sort of pretentious feeling which is a problem for some conversation heavy shows.  The dialogue was never cumbersome, each individual line of dialogue holds some variation of meaning and importance.  It can be utilized to establish characters with plenty of subtleties and quirks that give you a sense of their inner thoughts.  It reveals how Shichika’s personality and diction drastically changes like dialogue displaying sadness and jealousy, something his previous amoral self wouldn’t demonstrate.  The heavy amounts of dialogue can be boring for people, especially for those who are actiontards who only care about how the power of friendship can get them a random shounen powerup.  But if you listen and pay attention, the amount of subtlety and wittiness is an element that truly should be appreciated.  


Sometimes, because the show is dialogue heavy, the buildup to fights end up being anticlimactic with battles lasting less than 20 seconds.  This could be due to the fact that Nisio Isin is a huge troll because he takes what the audience anticipates and completely crushes them just for him to get a great laugh, sitting on his throne with piles of Monogatari money and body pillows while licking muddy feet that fetishy bastard.  But, as much as I love his trolling I won’t deny that at least 2 of the fights that were hyped up since the beginning of the show ended up leaving me disappointed in the end, and while I do understand why they were anticlimactic I felt as if a certain line was crossed by a tiny margin which left me with an empty feeling.  I felt like Donald Trump not kicking out a minority from a rally.  To make up for it the final episode features an excellently choreographed duel that may be one of my favorite fight scenes ever due to the high adrenaline and stakes.  The show could be called predictable since every episode you encounter a new person and it eventually ends with the retrieval of sword but in retrospect, the show throws insane amounts of curveballs to subvert the audience’s expectations.  This happens on multiple occasions, right when you think Katanagatari doesn’t have anything else it can surprise you with it somehow creeps from the shadows and slaps you in the face with something new.  And that’s what makes this series so engaging, it’s fresh and knows how to please its audience.


It’s freshness brings out an intriguing theme I’ve rarely witnessed in any medium which is the falsification of history but describing how this idea intertwines in Katanagatari will lead to spoilers.  All I’m going to say is that while it was handled extremely well, and is pretty ambitious, I personally found the explanations to be quite confusing but after skimming through the wiki I fully understood it.  Although, it was highly riveting and added a nice clean layer of fatalistic philosophy to the thematic orgy pot that gave the show an extra layer of intelligence.  In case you don’t understand what fatalism is because I’m a pretentious asshole, it is the belief that all events are predetermined and inevitable.  A specific character that is encountered later in the story can predict the future, and even though he realizes it's inevitable he attempts to change it anyways which plays a massive role in Katanagatari.


The show’s ending, depending on the viewpoint can either be extremely satisfying or dumb.  However, those people who say it’s dumb are incorrect!  The themes completely come full circle and though weird and unexpected, the ending closed off the story beautifully.


The characters

Aside from a few characters in Katanagatari, the sword wielders who wield the blades are limited to only one episode of screen time which is challenging in terms of establishing and making you genuinely care for these characters.  I’d say that Katanagatari executes an excellent job aside from a handful of characters.


Shichika takes the spotlight of the story.  In the beginning we see him as an amoral human that lacks any sort of emotion due to being secluded on an island all of his life.  It’s to the point where he initially is unable to feel any sort of sexual attraction towards Togame or other women.  What did this guy whack his meat to then? Trees?  Well, hey, the Na’vi from Avatar somewhat seduce trees so it’s possible.  His amorality initially made him extremely deadpan, always talking in a monotone manner.  However, his bland personality changes extremely.  As previously stated and might be somewhat redundant, The whole entire journey is about shaping him into a human through the various adventures embarks on and witnessing how the various emotions he accumulates affects his interactions with the characters and the world.  He learns such things as jealousy, compassion, intimacy, loneliness, and human unpredictability which evolves him from being just a mere sword to an actual genuine human.  They show his development rather than spewing it to the audience, it’s never like “YOU GAINED THE EMOTION OF JEALOUSY”, his actions speak rather than words.  In another episode with a man wielding an armor...sword...thing...Don’t question it, starts flirting with Togame leaving Shichika with a pissed off attitude without him realizing that he started to feel jealousy because he doesn’t understand full human emotions.  With all of these adventures you witness his personality change and it’s intriguing to observe how his newly found behaviors affect his interactions.  As he increasingly develops he actually starts shouldering guilt from those he killed in battle which is extremely humanlike and adds another layer of complexity to his character that I was surprised to see.  In addition to this we get a general glimpse into his backstory to observe where his amorality originated and how he adopted skills in the Kyoutouryu martial arts style.  Not to mention this man is a legitimate savage, this guy is a tall and powerful juggernaut of badassery that wrecks anyone and anything in his path and it’s a blast to see his obscure fighting style displayed onscreen.  Through quick witty remarks, self discovery, phenomenal amounts of development and intense fighting, Shichika is easily amongst my favorite male leads ever, right up there with good Ol’ sexy shirtless Onizuka...I’m straight, I just want Onizuka’s body tho.


Togame is hands down one of the most geniusly written female characters that this anime medium has yet to bestow in front my eyes.  Her outgoing personality easily gives her ample amounts of presence due to her dominating the conversation most of the time.  To dichotomize this, she bottles up plenty of negative emotions and inner demons that adds another layer to her character.  She is widely recognized for her exquisite ability to strategize schemes in order for her and Shichika to overcome strenuous situations.  When she’s scheming it is awesomely shown through the use of the snake eye she always have whenever she concocts a plan.  The snake eye also symbolically characterizes the inner workings of her character because while she may be filled with knowledge, the serpant equally represents her ruthless nature when it comes to how she achieves her goals.  Overall Togame is a strong female protagonist who feels like an actual character not attached to any archetype, has exceedingly clever dialogue, generates sensational character interactions with Shichika, and grows from her tragic backstory. She’s pretty cute too, I mean, look at those nice..round….eyes. Yum!


The maniwani are a weird furry loving clan who are opposing Shichika and Togame’s quest for the blades.  Since Katanagatari is insanely thematic, I believe that the Maniwani are supposed to represent loyalty since in about 90% of the scenes it is shown that they all rely on each other to reach their goal.  If one of their comrades gets murdered they they will stop at nothing to avenge their death which is highly appreciable.  They are divided into the bird, beast, insect and fish squads all containing, Weird *ss characters for a lack of a better term.  Their interactions fabricate some of the oddest bits of conversation when I say strange, oh my. They make Ikuhara appear normal, THE CREATOR OF GAY BEARS AND PENGUINS WITHOUT DRUMS... NORMAL?  NANI SORE?!?!?! .  It’s difficult not to spoil how abnormal they are but viewing the anime will validate my point.  However, I desired for them to be more fleshed out because they receive almost no development nor any reason to care about whenever one dies.  The deficit of any additional motivation driving them to fight and succeed also connects to that issue.  Overall, between the great action they provide, the quirkiness of their dialogue, and their extreme sense of loyalty creates interesting characters that sadly weren’t explored as thoroughly


The rest of the side characters as mentioned are for the most part well handled despite their short spotlight.  They actually take the time to elaborate on why a character acts in a specific way, why they wield their swords, and in some instances flesh them out quite a bit.  Each character has their own story to tell, and that’s what makes Katanagatari the greatness that it is, interconnecting stories that all intertwine with the general whole picture.  One of my favorites is the third episode which thematically was about compassion and the treatment of women in Edo Era Japan.  The character they focused on demonstrated her deep care for the suffering women at the shrine and even though she gave them all swords to feel self-empowered and validated she felt bad about how relying on their source of power will eventually poison them mentally.  It was a simple yet powerful story that was accomplished by allowing us to care about the female they focused on in the story.  Each character symbolically a certain human trait that Shichika is missing but at the same time they have more substance beyond just being a simple representation aside from 1 or 2 characters.  


The Art/Animation

Katanagatari has one of the most breathtaking and aesthetically pleasing art styles I have ever witnessed.  The multitude of colors for both the backgrounds and the environments manages to make every scene appear whimsical.  Sometimes, the backgrounds appear to be stripped right from an old Japanese portrait, it just gives off a truly remarkable artistic feeling that takes a heavy creative license.  Occasionally the lighting from the epic sunsets and the moon can be enticing with shading that fits with the show’s style. The different biomes also enhance the tone of the episode like the one that was set in a snowy biome to amplify the theme of loneliness and desolateness.  The designs for each character completely dichotomizes the stereotypical attire of Edo Era Japan with numerous zany and wacky designs that makes you wonder if the author was a cocaine addict.  Shichika’s design suits him well, with the upper half being shirtless to express his power while the leaves motif throughout his design could symbolize growth which is essentially what Shichika does within the entire series as a character.  The swords themselves are… Well, they’re great and all but don’t expect the conventional long handle sharp blade “Guts pierce me” type of sword.  Instead we got swords like a slice n dice sex doll and a sword without a blade.... weird, ain't it?  One huge complaint I have is episode 7 where the art style became bolder and was directed with tons of video game types of aesthetics that didn’t cooperate with the darker tone the episode set out to achieve.  While it totally didn’t kill the episode, I found it hard to take things seriously when I see Shichika’s sister slashing enemies from a top down view in a videogame-esque form, this isn’t legend of zelda four sword’s oh, I mean triforce heroes, blah it’s the same shit with one less sword fuck you Nintendo, it’s Katanagatari!  


The animation is delightful with ocassional quirks and minor movements to add flavor.  Katanagatari delivers without being inconsistent and leaving no scenes choppy and unloved.  The animation truly shines during the fight scenes with fluidity that would make Madhouse cry.  *Don’t worry madhouse, we know you dropped the ball on Overlord*. 


The Sound

The soundtrack for Katanagatari captures the beautiful essence of Edo Era Japan with many pieces adding to the overall atmosphere.  Bahasa Palus is amongst my favorites in the soundtrack, it’s a piece that utilizes vocal chants and is very upbeat, it’s usually played before a fight scene to get the viewer hyped.  Track 22 is reminiscent of the Making of a Cyborg track in Ghost in the Shell but has an entirely different feel that actually fits with the setting, it’s beautiful.  Those are only a couple of tracks but as a whole the OST invokes lots of emotion and adds some sugar, spice, and everything oh so nice to the atmosphere.  The opening songs are decent but the rebroadcast opening by Supercell is downright fantastic starting off with a slow melancholic melody but then instantly seduces your ears as the tempo increases.  The opening is literally the embodiment of what Katanagatari is, sad, adventurous and epic as all hell!.  The voice acting was a blessing to the ears, I felt like Jesus literally came down as I bent over and he gave my ears his divine love.  Shichika’s voice acting is awesome, initially very monotone which fits his personality and slowly as he accumulates emotions his voice alters generating steadily growing liveliness in his character.  Togame’s voice actress did an excellent job although her face looks like a compressed elephant’s head.  The playful nature of her character is amplified, her serious tone is demanding the audience’s attention and just CHEERIO!


Overall, Katanagatari was a blast to watch, the witty dialogue, explored themes, excellent leads, vibrant art style and eargasm soundtrack make for one of the best anime experiences I’ve ever had.  Standing in my top 15, Katanagatari is amongst one of my favorite anime and deserves a rating of Fantabulous, it is truly a piece of fiction that everyone should view if they consider themselves an anime fan.

Katanagatari is a historical fantasy anime revolving around a set of incredible cursed 'swords'. These incredibly powerful weapons corrupted anyone who would use them, and became known ad the Deviant Blades. The main characters are Togami, a short white-haired girl who has been tasked with the retrieval of these weapons, and Shinchika, a tall dark-haired martial artist who she enlists to do the actual fighting. What follows is a grand adventure across twelve episodes and most of the country as they do battle with these cursed weapons.
This is where the Story takes a bit of a left turn. The show has a very loose definitionof what a sword is, and as the episodes continue, the swords become increasingly bizarre and eventually impossible, hence the show existing as fantasy. There's also mentions of a prophesy, and the hint that the events of the series are being manipulated in some kind of grand scheme that reaches across time and space itself. To say more would be to spoil the plot entirely. What I can tell you is that while the plot is serviceable enough, that's what it is - a vehicle for everything else. 7/10.



The good news is, everything else is GREAT. The Art style is different, to say the least, and looks a bit like a fusion of Samurai Jack and Naruto. While you're getting your head around that bizarre visual, let me say that it's very pretty, though the minimalist method occasionally has you begging for more detail. 8/10.



The Sound design is pretty good, and let me say while the music itself does a great job of capturing the feeling behind the moment, the actual sound you're going to hear can get a bit annoying. Some of the twangyness from a few songs stuck with me like the auditory equivalent of gristle in my teeth - mildly unpleasant but not enough for me to reduce the volume. 7/10.



Characterization is the strongest aspect of this show by far. Shinchika and Togami have a wonderful dynamic that slowly progresses from episode to episode, and you can track specific qualities of their character growth with ease. Perhaps the best part of the characterization is how the protagonists always get to know the owner of the Deviant Blade before doing battle, and the human qualities we see in them create a subtle cognitive dissonance. Most of them are not using their weapons to do any harm, so are the protagonists the 'good guys'? The show never gives any easy answers, and at the very least the nature of the characters will stick with you long after the show is over and you've forgotten the plot.


One character in particular keeps this from a perfect score - Shinchika's sister. To explain the exact nature of her character would ruin the plot of at least two episodes, but in advance she's probably the greatest Mary Sue to ever exists. Episodes with her are entertaining, but her complete lack of meaningful flaws and poor character development make her a liability more than an asset. 9/10



I really enjoyed Katanagatari, far more than the studio's previous show Bakemonogatari. The relationship between characters feels natural, the fights are a fun mix of physical prowess and cerebral strategy and tactics, and the slower pacing of the show never felt like a hindrance, rather it gave the writers more time to explore the nature of the characters presented. 9/10


I give it a solid 8 out of ten. If you're looking to blow a full day (the episodes are 50 minutes each, not 22) and you're into historical fiction or martial arts, you'll have a good time. Just don't analyze the plot too much, and just roll with it.


As a final thought, I should mention that the final episode of the show is ALL payoff, and contains one of the most brutal, one-sided series of fights I have ever seen, culminating in an incredible final showdown that will leave you wanting to watch it all over again.

Episode #1 is out and here is the first review.
First of all I would like to talk about the plot. Right now it seems pretty simple if you read the synopsis of this anime, some dude (the main character) has to find 12 swords (makes me remember the old days of dragonball, then dragonball Z). Plot seems simple and staight forward, but I feel that we are in for a few twists.
Based on the fact that there seems to be only 12 episodes to be released, Katanagatari should have a lot of action in a 46 minute slot, and I have a feeling that alot of minor details, that could make this story a lot better might be left out. 


The artwork is simple in this anime. I think that the animators were going more for the history and principles behind the animation series, rather than boost it up with special effects. So if you are looking for state of the art graphics, you will not find it in this series. 


Sound effects, background music, and other sonar stimulants seem to be well adapted to the story. I will not comment much right now since it is too soon to really know. 


The Characters are simple and seem to go back to the basics, but I feel that they will become very rich in the future as the story evolves.


I found this anime to be quite interesting, and I am looking forward to the next episodes to see what happens.


Thank You.

Katanagatari. Wow.
If you'd like just stop here. You should really watch this show. I'm a little fan boy. Everything is pretty damn good.
However the determined/stubborn/time wasting reader may have proceeded further into this review and for those rare people I now review and stop wasting your time.
Katanagatari is a unique show written by Nisio Isin, one of my favorite writers, famous for shows such as the mess that is the Bakemonogatari franchise and the Medaka Box. If you've seen/read either of these works then you know what to expect, fascinating characters mixed in with an interesting plot and with healthy doses of comedy.
Story-10
My poor knowledgeof the Japanese language (mostly based off ramen and noodles) says that Katanagatari literally translates as "sword" and "story". 

This is in short a story about collecting 12 magical swords forged by the great sword smith Shikizaki Kiki. The two leads Yasuri Shichika and Togame the Strategian must work to traverse Edo-era Japan to collect the swords on their way defeating traitorous ninjas, ex-bandits and the shades of their past (literally). 

However this description does not truly do the show justice. On the surface the series appears as a fairly typical shounen-esque romp through a famous period in Japanese history. But the true meanings about legacy and duty are something that requires a good deal more thought and introspection. 

Luckily the viewer will definitely have time for this as the 50 minute long episodes are extremely dialogue heavy (as expected from a show by the same writer as Bakemonogatari).

Without spoiling the show hits hard and is very, very clever.


Art-9   

The art style for the show is once again fairly unique being relatively simplistic but with a lot of attention to detail. Personally it is beautiful. Elements such as the symbolism in the clothes that each character wears, to the variation and scope of the background scenes as the characters travel the land, really brought me into the world they were depicting. The fight scenes are also for the most part fantastically choreographed and animated, which means the show still gets by as an action show to a degree.

My only criticisms would be episode 7 which animated in an entirely different (and personally much lower quality) style which did make a low point of an episode which would of otherwise have been the high point of the show.

Also the fight scenes do disappoint towards the end either due to lack of budget(?) or just as an attempt to how show increasing power. A little bit sad but not breaking in any way.


Sound-9

Once again they hit home and do it hard. 

The OP and ED are both acceptable but after the first repetition I did just skip them as neither competed in any way to the glory that is the show. Shame.

However the music throughout the show is fantastic with the highlight being “Bahasa Palus” which I may have been playing on loop constantly while writing this. Music fits the tone of the scene perfectly in all scenes ranging between the epic fight scenes to the casual comedy. What more can you ask for?

Voice acting is also superb (from the point of view of someone who speaks no Japanese). Special props go to Yoshimasa Hosoya for his role is Shichika and my personal favourite Yukari Tamura as Togame who carries out the role of a fantastic character amazingly (also appears as  Remon from Ano Natsu, Rika from Higurashi and Seppuku bunny from Kampfer (for you true artisans of taste)). 


Character-10

Where the show truly shines. 

All of the leads are interesting, well developed characters, with driving motives behind their actions and decisions. 

Our lead is Yasuri Shichika the orphaned son of the Kyoto Ryu family and current head. The strength in his character comes from his isolation from early childhood which leaves him with a unique world view and value system which places him many rungs above the shallow character he may initially appear as.

Next is Togame the self-appointed Strategian of the Shogunate who seeks the swords for her own goals and desire for power for reasons not entirely made clear *hint hint*. Togame plays the dual role of the fragile genius and the source of a good deal of the feels in this show, and my, there are a lot of feels. 

The rest of the cast is extensive with a number of other main roles along with a large cast newly introduced each week in a cowboy beepbop-esque manner (Phrase stolen from a certain Demodeezy). New characters are seen each week and often discarded immediately afterwards but each is developed to an extent that few shows can match, and that in such a way that their effects on the characters are seen long afterwards. It is done extremely well with each one used to convey a small part of the overall message of the show.


Enjoyment-10

Very much so. 

In case my gushing has not conveyed this I really quite liked this show. It is filled with deep meaning, symbolism and thoughts that pull together to make a true gem of an experience.

The show does something which I always feel the best anime’s do and that is be fluid in how they present their world encompassing many emotions into each episode with action, comedy, romance and sadness all shown in equal measures. (though some hurt more). The 50 minute run time for each episode can make it daunting and less casual. The lack of a dub is also significant with the sheer volume of words often thrown at the screen being overwhelming at times. However the show is a true treat.


Overall-10


Watch it.

You won’t regret it. 

Unless you get emotionally scarred easily. 

Or if you have human emotions.

It’s sad okay!
